keyTakeAways: An oil tanker explosion in Niger state, Nigeria, on 2025-10-22, resulted in at least 30 deaths and over 40 injuries as villagers collected spilled fuel.
The tanker, carrying petroleum from Lagos to the north, crashed due to poor road conditions on the Bida-Agaie road near Essan and Badeggi communities.
Multiple deaths and injuries are attributed to the villagers' actions of scooping fuel from the overturned tanker, despite repeated warnings.

This incident is part of a broader pattern of tanker-related tragedies in Nigeria, including a similar explosion in Jigawa state in October 2024 that killed 153 people and another in Suleja, Niger state, in January 2025 that killed 86.
Niger State Governor Mohammed Umaru Bago described the incident as 'worrisome, unfortunate and pathetic', citing a lack of public awareness despite repeated awareness campaigns.
The Federal Road Safety Corps and National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) reported conflicting numbers: 35 dead (FRSC) and 29 dead (NEMA) with 42 injured.
Poor road conditions are identified as a major contributor to the crash and the subsequent disaster.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In an oil tanker explosion in Niger state, Nigeria, on 2025-10-22, dozens of villagers died after collecting spilled fuel from a tanker that had crashed due to poor road conditions on the Bida-Agaie road near Essan and Badeggi. The incident, which resulted in at least 29 to 35 deaths and over 40 injuries, reflects a recurring pattern of tragedies in Nigeria, including a 2024 explosion in Jigawa state that killed 153 and a 2025 incident in Suleja that killed 86. Despite repeated awareness campaigns, villagers continue to collect fuel from overturned tankers, a dangerous practice highlighted by state officials. The Nigerian government agencies, including the Federal Road Safety Corps and National Emergency Management Agency, reported conflicting casualty figures, indicating challenges in accurate reporting. The disaster underscores systemic issues such as poor road infrastructure, inadequate public awareness, and the high risk of fuel-related accidents in Nigeria’s oil transport network.
title: Nigeria tanker explosion: Dozens killed scooping fuel in Niger state
